resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
jorisvandenbossche commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r989777443


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
      and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and ``arrow_python`` library
   ```



##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ C++ API
 
 .. default-domain:: cpp
 
-The Arrow C++ header files are bundled with a pyarrow installation.
+The Arrow C++ and Pyarrow C++ header files are bundled with a pyarrow installation.

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
   The Arrow C++ and PyArrow C++ header files are bundled with a pyarrow installation.
   ```



##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   Should we add something like ".. and will no longer be automatically findable by CMake"? 
   
   We no longer install an ArrowPython cmake config file in `/lib/cmake`, so my understanding is that `find_package(arrow_python)` in CMake therefore won't work anymore? 
   
   cc @kou @pitrou

kou commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r989799690


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   Ah, right.
   
   Can we suggest our C data/stream interface as an alternative of `arrow/python/api.h`?

jorisvandenbossche commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r991892776


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   I suppose we could suggest that as an alternative depending on your use cases, but there are more things the pyarrow C++ API let you do than just converting arrays / tables between python and C++, so it's not a full replacement.
   
   And you still have the Arrow C++ dependency, so I am not sure if avoiding the pyarrow C++ dependency gives then that much of benefit? (regarding building/packaging complexity)

kou commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r991901657


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   It's not my use case. I was thinking about this case: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-16340?focusedCommentId=17612958#comment-17612958

pitrou commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r991906860


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library

Review Comment:
   I think we should still support the wrap/unwrap functions [as documented](https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/integration/extending.html).

AlenkaF commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r992031604


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   Would it work if I added something similar to:
   ".. and will no longer be automatically findable by CMake. For a subset of functionality available in PyArrow C++ API one can use C [data](https://arrow.apache.org/docs/dev/format/CDataInterface.html)/[stream](https://arrow.apache.org/docs/dev/format/CStreamInterface.html) interface as an alternative."

pitrou commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r992039428


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   IMHO there is not point in advertising the C Data Interface as an alternative, since the PyArrow C++ API is still there.

 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add

jorisvandenbossche commented on code in PR #14333:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14333#discussion_r992258072


##########
docs/source/python/integration/extending.rst:
##########
@@ -50,12 +50,23 @@ This will not include other parts of the Arrow API, which you will need
 to include yourself (for example ``arrow/api.h``).
 
 When building C extensions that use the Arrow C++ libraries, you must add
-appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pyarrow.get_libraries``
-and ``pyarrow.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
+appropriate linker flags. We have provided functions ``pa.get_libraries``
+and ``pa.get_library_dirs`` which return a list of library names and
 likely library install locations (if you installed pyarrow with pip or
 conda). These must be included when declaring your C extensions with
 setuptools (see below).
 
+.. note::
+
+   The PyArrow-specific C++ code is now a part of the PyArrow source tree
+   and not Arrow C++. That means the header files and arrow_python library
+   are not necessarily installed in the same location as that of Arrow.

Review Comment:
   Yes, and for this specific use case (and if you are already building against arrow anyway), using the C Data Interface is also more complex than using of the wrap/unwrap functions.
   
   @AlenkaF I would still add something along the lines of ".. and will no longer be automatically findable by CMake" (my original comment in this thread)

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
We should add a not to the documentation: [https://arrow.apache.org/docs/dev/python/integration/extending.html#c-api]

explaining that the location of the PyArrow C++ header files and arrow_python lib has changed and that the users need to use the information from the Integration -> Extending page to get the new location.
fields.summary: [Docs][Python] Add more info about the change in PyArrow C++ API
